author: Special Correspondent
text:
India and the U.K. have jointly launched a funding programme and have invited proposals in the areas of clean technology, affordable healthcare, and Information and Communication Technology with focus on commercialisation of products, said Bharat Joshi, British Deputy High Commissioner in Chennai, here on Friday.

Speaking at the UK Alumni Meet 2016 (Glocalising Innovation), organised by the British Deputy High Commission, Chennai, in partnership with the Association of British Scholars, Coimbatore, he said co-investment by India and the U.K. in supporting joint research activities has risen from one million pounds in 2009 to around 200 million pounds now.

The UK India Education and Research initiative has supported over 1,000 partnerships, including over 380 from 2011, since its inception in 2006. Companies that are UK-based offer innovative skills delivery.

“UK and India have affirmed their support for a strong partnership in skill development and noted the opportunities in the delivery of vocational skills in all sectors to achieve the target of training 500 million by 2020,” he said.

Shweta Midha from the British High Commission, New Delhi, spoke about Chevening Scholarships. Chevening Awards in India include scholarships for one year Master’s programme and fellowship for short-term programme, which is for mid-career professionals.
title: India and UK launch funding programme
